answers.q: is locust bean gum bad for you
answers.a: No—locust bean gum (E410) is generally recognized as safe, and EFSA sets an ADI of “not specified”; most people tolerate the small amounts used in foods, though larger amounts can cause gas or loose stools.

answers.q: can dogs have locust bean gum
answers.a: Yes, small amounts as found in commercial dog foods are generally safe and commonly used as a thickener; too much may cause mild digestive upset in sensitive dogs.

answers.q: is carob bean gum bad for you
answers.a: No—carob (locust) bean gum is considered safe at typical food levels; it has low toxicity, though high intakes can cause bloating or loose stools in some people.

answers.q: can dogs have carob bean gum
answers.a: Yes, in the small quantities used in pet foods it’s generally safe for dogs, but large amounts may lead to gas or soft stools.

answers.q: can dogs eat locust bean gum
answers.a: In small amounts, yes—it's commonly used in dog foods and treats and considered safe; avoid large quantities that could upset the stomach.
